an8.10:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggara Lotus Pond.
an8.10:4.2: Now at that time the mendicants accused a mendicant of an offence.
an8.10:4.3: The accused mendicant dodged the issue, distracted the discussion with irrelevant points, and displayed irritation, hate, and bitterness.
an8.10:5.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
an8.10:5.4: This person should be shown the door.
an8.10:5.5: Why should you be vexed by an outsider?
an8.10:5.6: Take a case where a certain person looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.
an8.10:5.7: That is, so long as the mendicants don’t notice his offence.
an8.10:5.8: But when the mendicants notice the offence, they know that he’s
an8.10:5.9: a corrupt ascetic, just useless trash.
an8.10:5.10: When they realize this they send him away.
an8.10:5.12: So that he doesn’t corrupt good-natured mendicants.

an8.10:8.2: Then the owners take a broom and sweep them even further away.
an8.10:8.4: So that it doesn’t spoil the good grain.

an8.10:9.1: Suppose a man needs an irrigation gutter for a well. He’d take a sharp axe and enter the wood,
an8.10:9.2: where he’d knock various trees with the axe. The trees that were firm and substantial made a cracking sound.
an8.10:9.3: But the trees that were rotten inside, hollow and decayed, made a thud.
an8.10:9.4: He’d cut down such a tree at the root, lop off the crown, and thoroughly clear out the insides. Then he’d use it as an irrigation gutter for the well.
an8.10:9.5: In the same way, take a case where a certain person looks just the same as other good-natured mendicants when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.
